author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Confronting Grief, With Margaret Atwood, in ‘The Nurse Antigone’
description: A dramatic reading by Theater of War Productions will include the author and practicing nurses who have held the front line of the pandemic.
content: It was a tragedy — an ancient Greek tragedy — that brought together three nurses on a Zoom call one night last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin Assails Russians Who Back the West, Signaling More Repression
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia denigrated European and American leaders, and Russians who disagreed with him. Analysts fear his remarks could signal a new wave of repression.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday referred to pro-Western Russians as “scum and traitors” who needed to be removed from society, describing the war in Ukraine as part of an existential clash with the United States and setting the stage for an ever fiercer crackdown at home and even more aggression abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Warehouses Transform N.Y.C. Neighborhoods as E-Commerce Booms
description: The region is home to the largest concentration of online shoppers in the country. The facilities, key to delivering packages on time, are reshaping neighborhoods.
content: An e-commerce boom turbocharged by the pandemic is turning the New York City region into a national warehouse capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jussie Smollett Released From Jail on Order of Appellate Court
description: The appellate court ruled that he be released on bond pending his appeal of a judge’s sentence that he serve five months in jail.
content: An Illinois appellate court ruled Wednesday that the actor Jussie Smollett be released from jail on bond pending his appeal of his conviction for falsely reporting that he had been the victim of a hate crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Marlise Simons
title: Mass Graves Identified in Syria Could Hold Evidence of War Crimes
description: Two sites have been located, believed to hold thousands of bodies of Syrians killed in detention centers administered by President Bashar al-Assad’s government during the civil war.
content: BERLIN — By day, the workers used heavy machinery to dig pits and trenches. After dark, the corpses arrived, sometimes hundreds at a time, in the beds of military pickups or in refrigerator trucks meant for transporting food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: A clandestine visit by European leaders to Ukraine.
content: The leaders of Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia traveled to Kyiv, Ukraine’s besieged capital, in a defiant show of support yesterday, even as a relentless Russian artillery bombardment left apartment towers in the city ablaze, forcing terrified residents to flee into the street with only the clothes on their backs. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jose Solís
title: Heather Christian’s Choral Work Is a Study of Time. Patience, Too.
description: The composer’s “Oratorio for Living Things,” forced to shut down because of the pandemic, returns to the Ars Nova stage in Manhattan.
content: On a strangely comforting morning in early March, the composer Heather Christian made her way to Ars Nova’s space in Greenwich Village, Manhattan, for the first time in two years. The bright sun, radiating the warmth of a spring day, was enough to momentarily make her forget she was freezing. Once inside, she re-encountered the set for her delicately epic choral piece “Oratorio for Living Things,” which had two preview performances before the pandemic hit, and is back, running through April 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: March Madness
description: Have you filled out a bracket or joined a pool? What predictions can you make?
content: How do you feel about March Madness? Have you filled out a bracket or joined a pool?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: The Video That Changed the N.C.A.A.
description: One 38-second clip showing differences between the men’s and women’s tournaments led to profound overhauls in gender parity.
content: Today, the story of one TikTok that changed the N.C.A.A. forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At Indian Wells, a Shot of Optimism for American Men’s Tennis
description: Long without a major tournament champion, the United States has four players in the round of 16 at the BNP Paribas Open and seven in the top 50.
content: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — False dawns in American men’s tennis? There have been quite a few in the last 20 years here in the California desert and in more well-watered parts of the pro circuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: In ‘Lessons From the Edge,’ How an Ambassador to Ukraine Became a Casualty of the Trump Administration
description: Marie Yovanovitch recounts her career in public service and the experience of testifying during President Trump’s first impeachment.
content: When Marie Yovanovitch was abruptly recalled from her post as the United States ambassador to Ukraine, the timing felt surreal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Officers Said They Hoped Black Lives Matter Protesters Would Die, Suit Says
description: Mark Miles, a Black officer with the Maryland-National Capital Park Police, says in a lawsuit that his white supervisor and other officers made hateful comments in a work-related text chain.
content: In a series of text messages, a white supervisor and other police officers in Montgomery County, Md., talked about preparing for a “race war,” and expressed hope that Black Lives Matter protesters would be killed, according to a federal lawsuit filed this week by a Black colleague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: loathe
description: This word has appeared in 69 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word loathe has appeared in 69 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 30 in the Opinion essay “How Could I Ever Love Michigan State?” by Jane Coaston:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry J. Farrell and Abraham L. Newman
title: The U.S. Is the Only Sanctions Superpower. It Must Use That Power Wisely.
description: Overreach could be disastrous.
content: For years, many believed that a world of global economic networks and interdependence — countries intimately connected via supply chains and finances — made war obsolete. That is part of the reason Russia’s invasion of Ukraine was so shocking. But the international economy itself has turned into a battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Putin’s War on Ukraine Is About Ethnicity and Empire
description: Biden’s framework of ‘democracies versus autocracies’ misses the darker source of this war, which has deep roots in Russian history and thought.
content: BRUSSELS — President Biden took office with the idea that this century’s struggle would be between the world’s democracies and autocracies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: The Economy’s Terrible, G.O.P. Governors Say. Just Not in Their States.
description: In Maryland, Florida and other states, Republican governors have been attacking the national economy while boasting about the one in their states. Economists say it defies logic.
content: In speeches and media appearances, Republican governors are savaging President Biden for policies they say are wrecking the U.S. economy as a whole. But in the particulars — in their own states, in other words — the economy’s booming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: What Makes a Times Article Go Viral?
description: Facebook posts, shares, emails and page views: We may already know how an article spreads online, but we’re still learning why it lights up the internet.
content: It started as a typical Tuesday for Amanda Hess, a critic at large at The New York Times. At 10 a.m., an article she had written was published on The Times’s website. But a few hours later, while she was filing her taxes, she received a surprising Slack message from her editor. “You’re the most read thing on the site,” her editor wrote. By 10 p.m., the article was getting thousands of views per minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Hoffman
title: She Became a Private Eye. And Investigated Her Past.
description: In “Tell Me Everything: The Story of a Private Investigation,” Erika Krouse tells twin stories of working a case and exploring personal trauma.
content: TELL ME EVERYTHINGThe Story of a Private InvestigationBy Erika Krouse
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Cellular Meat, Emotional Intelligence, Palau
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about cellular chicken, reflect on emotional intelligence, interpret an image with a brick on top of an egg, learn about Palau and try to figure out what’s happening in a photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lesley M. M. Blume
title: Truth Is the First Casualty of War. These Reporters Tried to Save It.
description: Deborah Cohen’s “Last Call at the Hotel Imperial” tells the story of four foreign correspondents who sounded the alarm from Europe before World War II.
content: LAST CALL AT THE HOTEL IMPERIALThe Reporters Who Took On a World at WarBy Deborah Cohen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley and Nydia Blas
title: The Artists Turning Nina Simone’s Childhood Home Into a Creative Destination
description: Rashid Johnson, Julie Mehretu, Adam Pendleton and Ellen Gallagher are working both to preserve and transform the North Carolina house where she was born.
content: IN 1997, WHEN he was 20 years old, the New York-based artist Rashid Johnson traveled with a friend from their hometown, Chicago, to Ghana, on a pilgrimage to the final resting place of the most prominent Black intellectual of the 20th century, W.E.B. Du Bois. Arriving in Accra, Johnson enacted a ritual familiar to Black Americans across generations: that of searching for home in a lost ancestral past. More than 30 years earlier, in 1961, Du Bois, disillusioned after a life spent fighting Jim Crow racism, had left the United States for Ghana at the invitation of the Ghanaian president Kwame Nkrumah. Two years later, he became a Ghanaian citizen, and on Aug. 27, 1963, the eve of the March on Washington, he died. “I remember just being in this house and feeling his presence,” Johnson, now 45, recalls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner, Kenneth P. Vogel and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Hunter Biden Paid Tax Bill, but Broad Federal Investigation Continues
description: The Justice Department inquiry into the business dealings of the president’s son has remained active, with a grand jury seeking information about payments from around the world.
content: WASHINGTON — In the year after he disclosed a federal investigation into his “tax affairs” in late 2020, President Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, paid off a significant tax liability, even as a grand jury continued to gather evidence in a wide-ranging examination of his international business dealings, according to people familiar with the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Eric Nagourney
title: Powerful Quake Off Japan Rekindles Fears of Another Fukushima
description: Tsunami warnings in a region hit by nuclear disaster in 2011 were lifted after a few hours. The damage was still being assessed, but it appeared contained.
content: TOKYO — A powerful undersea earthquake off the Fukushima region of Japan, where a tsunami a decade ago set off one of the worst nuclear plant disasters in history, shook buildings for more than two minutes late Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Imagining Peace in Ukraine
description: Is it possible? And what could it look like?
content: Vladimir Putin’s history makes it hard to imagine a peace agreement in which an independent Ukraine continues to exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Jan Ransom
title: Rikers Still ‘Unstable and Unsafe’ Under New Jails Chief, Watchdog Says
description: A federal monitor overseeing reforms at the troubled New York City jail complex said staffing problems and high rates of violence persist.
content: Despite New York City’s claims to have made progress in remedying the crisis on Rikers Island, the jail complex remains awash in violence and disorder fed by chronic staff absenteeism, according to a report filed Wednesday in federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From a Vermont Sanctuary to Chicago’s Spoken Word
description: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: ALL THE FLOWERS KNEELING, by Paul Tran. (Penguin Books, paper, $18.) “My purpose is precision,” Tran writes in this powerful debut, which marshals narrative lyrics and stark beauty (bioluminescence, “ochre-stained shells”) to address personal and political violence. “Even when I’m unclear I’m deliberate. / When I’m deliberate I’m liberated.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: After MoMA Stabbings, Museums Review Their Safety Protocols
description: Violent acts in museums are rare, experts say, but the seriousness of the recent attack at the Museum of Modern Art has focused attention on protecting visitors and employees.
content: Karissa Francis has seen her fair share of drama in the seven years she has worked as a visitor services assistant in museum lobbies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Trinity Irish Dance Company Review: Those Flashing, Percussive Feet
description: This Chicago company presents Irish dance of great skill, while trying, sometimes successfully, to modernize and invigorate the tradition.
content: St. Patrick’s Day is at hand, and that’s why Trinity Irish Dance Company is in from Chicago to perform at the Joyce Theater this week. As Brendan O’Shea, the affable lead singer of the troupe’s house band, joked on Tuesday, “They let us in.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: ‘Hart Island’ Gives Voice to Stories That Might Otherwise Be Lost
description: Tracy Weller’s new multimedia theater piece focuses on those buried in New York City’s potter’s field and the inmates who dug the graves there.
content: What we know about Hart Island, one of the largest mass grave sites in the country, we know from fragments. Fragments of history, memory, testimony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: In Art and Tennis, Watch Out for the Backhand
description: Jane Campion’s comment about Venus and Serena Williams reminded our critic of his own night of ‘botched fanciness’ and racial slights.
content: Something about the way the director Jane Campion went overboard on Sunday to identify with, then insult, Venus and Serena Williams at an awards show brought to mind a night of botched fanciness that happened to me. A couple Fridays ago, I went to see some art: a Faith Ringgold retrospective at the New Museum in the afternoon, with friends; Norm Lewis singing at Carnegie Hall in the evening. (That was a solo trip.) For both, I wore a suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody García and Natalie Kitroeff
title: In Reversal, Guatemala Shelves Anti-Abortion Law
description: President Alejandro Giammattei said he would veto the bill days after his allies pushed it through the legislature, a move that surprised analysts, human rights activists and officials.
content: GUATEMALA CITY — Guatemala’s congress on Tuesday shelved a bill that would have imposed up to 10 years of jail time for women who obtained abortions, an abrupt reversal that follows days of protests, legal challenges and widespread disapproval of the measure, including from a prominent anti-abortion group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: ‘Turning Red’ Is a Good Conversation Starter — and Not Just for Girls
description: Some parents don’t like its depictions of adolescent rebellion, periods and sexuality, but experts say those topics are appropriate for family discussion.
content: Disney’s newest animated film, “Turning Red,” in which an adolescent girl contends with puberty, cultural expectations and her newfound tendency to turn into a giant red panda when overtaken by emotion, has viewers buzzing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Histories of Travel Segregation and Chinese Migration Win Bancroft Prize
description: The scholars Mia Bay and Mae Ngai have won the award, considered one of the most prestigious in the field of American history.
content: An innovative study of Black Americans’ struggle against discrimination in transportation and a sweeping examination of Chinese migration to goldfields across the Anglophone world in the 19th century have won this year’s Bancroft Prize, which is considered one of the most prestigious honors in the field of American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How to Outlast 5-Minute Internet Fads
description: Hand videos by the food entertainment site Tasty reshaped the internet. The question now is what’s next.
content: We live in an online world made by Tasty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Zelensky Speaks to Congress
description: Plus an offshore earthquake in Japan and mass graves in Syria.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine pleaded on Wednesday for more weapons and sanctions, showing searing footage of civilian casualties during a virtual address to U.S. lawmakers. In a remarkably direct appeal, he invoked the memories of Pearl Harbor and the Sept. 11 attacks. “We need you right now,” he said. “I call on you to do more.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: Chilling New Details Emerge of Shooting Spree Targeting Homeless Men
description: Prosecutors paint a disturbing picture of a man who they said was on a murderous rampage against the most vulnerable.
content: The first time the gunman struck in Washington, he hovered over his victim and shot him three times as a train passed. The second time, prosecutors said, he shot the victim in the head, face, chest, thigh and buttocks, then sat on a curb playing loud music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Will the Fed Cause a Recession?
description: Here’s an argument against aggressively raising interest rates to stop inflation.
content: The economist David Rosenberg says it’s not just possible but likely that the U.S. economy will fall into a recession this year, partly because, he says, the Federal Reserve will go too far in raising interest rates to fight inflation, which is at a 40-year high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Russian sanctions could create ‘supply crisis’ as oil output falls.
description: The International Energy Agency said the global economy could be whipsawed by cuts in oil supplies and a sharp drop in demand.
content: The International Energy Agency warned on Wednesday that the global economy could be whipsawed by both disruptions to oil supplies and a sharp fall in demand resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Manhattan’s borough president and a former mayoral aide propose a plan to get more New Yorkers their boosters.
description: The plan, from the borough president Mark Levine and Dr. Jay Varma, a top health adviser to the former mayor, comes as the current mayor, Eric Adams, has been aggressively promoting efforts to rebuild the city’s economy in recent weeks.
content: Mark Levine, the Manhattan borough president, and Dr. Jay Varma, a top health adviser to former Mayor Bill de Blasio, called on the city on Wednesday for a plan to encourage New Yorkers to get their booster shots and protect residents from any future waves of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Raphael Minder
title: Saharan Sands Float North to Europe, Coating Cities With Dust
description: A European monitoring service projected that the dust, which cast an eerie orange pall over much of the continent, could reach as far as Denmark.
content: Dust from the Sahara drifted north into Europe for a second day on Wednesday, coating parked cars in a rusty, reddish layer in Spain and creating an ominous orange glow in skies across the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Joe Buck and Troy Aikman to Host ‘Monday Night Football’
description: Their multiyear deals will make the duo, who have called games together for 20 N.F.L. seasons, among the highest-paid sports broadcasters.
content: “Monday Night Football” will be brought to you by Fox next N.F.L. season — the faces and voices behind Fox Sports, that is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rikki Novetsky, Diana Nguyen, Mooj Zadie, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Inflation Lessons From the 1970s
description: Painful lessons from the past have helped convince policymakers that quickly raising interest rates is the way to combat rising prices.
content: With prices on the rise in the U.S. economy, the Federal Reserve is expected to announce on Wednesday an increase in interest rates, essentially pouring a cold glass of water on the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kaminer
title: House Hunting in Luxembourg: A Modern Cottage Built for Efficiency
description: With foreigners streaming in and inventory struggling to keep pace, the tiny country is demanding some ‘totally insane’ prices, local brokers say.
content: Built with local wood and engineered for energy efficiency, this four-bedroom house is in Mertzig, Luxembourg, about 23 miles northwest of the capital, Luxembourg City. Belgian architecture firm Crahay & Jamaigne designed the home, which was constructed in 2011 by Luxembourg builder Naturhome, a specialist in wood houses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: A Proud Dad in the Stands, Omar Minaya Is Still a Scout at Heart
description: Throughout the season, Minaya, a former Mets general manager, has watched his son Justin play for Providence and shared his opinions on potential pros with his contacts in the N.B.A.
content: When Justin Minaya and fourth-seeded Providence take the court in Buffalo on Thursday for their first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game against 13th-seeded South Dakota State, there will be one keenly interested scout in the stands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Langewiesche
title: The War for the Rainforest
description: Set aside for an isolated Indigenous group, the Brazilian preserve Ituna-Itatá has now been heavily deforested — a grim illustration of the intractable forces destroying the Amazon.
content: On a sweltering afternoon in the wilds of the Brazilian Amazon, Edward Luz rode on the back of a motorbike into a forest clearing to confront a squad of combat-armed environmental police who, for their own safety, had helicoptered in. Luz is an anthropologist, a tall, powerfully built man of 43. He is a right-wing activist and, figuratively speaking, a hired gun. On that February afternoon in 2020, he wore tinted prescription sunglasses, a bushy beard and a radical haircut close-cropped on the sides. He did not have access to a helicopter. To get to the clearing, he traveled for eight hours by a ferry crossing and down muddy tracks from Altamira, a small city in the state of Pará on the far side of the wide brown Xingu river.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jean Potvin, Part of the 1980s Islanders’ N.H.L. Dynasty, Dies at 72
description: He was traded to New York in 1973, when they were an awful expansion team, but became part of a fast-improving franchise that won its first two Stanley Cups in 1980 and ’81.
content: Jean Potvin, a defenseman who played on the first two of the New York Islanders’ four Stanley Cup championships in the 1980s, died on Tuesday in Westin, Fla. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Mushrooms and Speed at Alexander McQueen
description: The luxury brand held its first New York runway show in more than 20 years.
content: Alexander McQueen returned to New York, for one night only, with several large piles of pungent dirt and wood chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $475,000 Homes in Massachusetts, the District of Columbia and Arkansas
description: A bungalow in Great Barrington, a two-bedroom cottage in Washington and a 1955 ranch house in Little Rock.
content: Great Barrington is one of Berkshire County’s most popular year-round destinations: Spring and summer bring hikers; autumn attracts leaf-peepers; and winter draws skiers and snowboarders. Butternut Ski Area and Tubing Center, on the edge of East Mountain State Forest, is five minutes away by car, as is an access point to the Appalachian Trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: A Fox News journalist who was injured in Ukraine is now ‘safe.’
description: Benjamin Hall was seriously injured in an incident that killed a Fox News cameraman and a young Ukrainian journalist.
content: Benjamin Hall, the Fox News correspondent who was seriously injured when his vehicle came under fire outside Kyiv on Monday, is now safe and being treated outside of Ukraine, the network said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Mercedes opens a battery plant in Alabama, part of a Southern wave.
description: The German automaker, which has made cars in the state for decades, has invested $1 billion in a factory to supply the power for electric vehicles.
content: WOODSTOCK, Ala. — The auto industry’s shift to battery power is expected to lead to job losses because it takes fewer workers to build an electric vehicle than it does to build a car with a gasoline engine. But that probably won’t be the case in Alabama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Annotated Transcript: Zelensky’s Speech to Congress
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed a joint meeting of the House and Senate to press his case for more aid to Ukraine amid devastating attacks by Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made an urgent and searing appeal to Congress on Wednesday to come to his country’s aid as it fights off a devastating Russian invasion, casting the war as a battle for the cause of democracy itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo and Jane Bradley
title: Oligarchs Got Richer Despite Sanctions. Will This Time Be Different?
description: For nearly a decade, sanctions have been little more than names on a list for wealthy Russians. Governments are working to give them bite.
content: The first time the United States government slapped his family with sanctions and locked him out of the American financial system, Arkady Rotenberg waited about eight weeks, investigators say, before buying a $7.5 million painting in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Retail sales rose in February, but inflation is starting to take its toll on spending.
description: Sales rose 0.3 percent from January, a sharp slowdown in growth. Spending at electronics, appliance, furniture, health and personal care stores was lower.
content: Retail sales rose 0.3 percent in February from the prior month, the Commerce Department reported on Wednesday, a slowdown in spending that suggested inflation was taking its toll on American consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Hiram Maristany, 76, Dies; ‘People’s Photographer’ of Spanish Harlem
description: He sought to depict his community “from the inside out” and to challenge negative images of Puerto Ricans in New York.
content: Hiram Maristany, a self-taught photographer who documented both Spanish Harlem’s everyday rigors and its vigorous cultural legacy from the inside for nearly six decades, died on March 10 in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Question of Default
description: Russian debt faces an uncertain future.
content: Today is the beginning of what is likely a long battle over Russian debt, with $117 million in interest payments due on the government’s dollar-denominated bonds. If Russia fails to make the payments, that could be its first default on foreign debt since the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. The Times’s Eshe Nelson, Alan Rappeport and DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch took a look at what’s at stake — and what could happen next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell and Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks C.E.O. retires, and Howard Schultz steps in as interim chief executive.
description: Kevin Johnson, who was named chief executive in 2017, will leave his post on April 4.
content: For the past two years, even as the pandemic shut down key markets and created supply shortages, Kevin Johnson, the chief executive of Starbucks, managed to lead the company to robust revenue and profit growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: When the Orchestra Is the Star of the Opera
description: Singers tended to fade into the background in a concert presentation of “Wozzeck” and some productions at the Metropolitan Opera.
content: Deep in his brooding, bitter opera “Wozzeck,” Alban Berg evokes a soldiers’ barracks in the dead of night. A choir chants: a faint, wordless gauze, punctuated by the strangled stabs of a double bass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Cristian Movila
title: Refugee Crisis Will Test a European Economy Under Pressure
description: Resettling the refugees fleeing Ukraine could cost $30 billion in the first year alone, and the permanent integration of millions of people would reshape Europe’s economy.
content: Nearly everyone who crossed the Danube on the open-air ferry from Ukraine and landed in the frostbitten Romanian port city of Isaccea on a recent morning had a roller bag and a stopgap plan. One woman planned to join her husband in Istanbul. Another was headed to Munich, where her company has its headquarters. Others were meeting brothers, cousins, in-laws and friends in Paris or Sofia, Madrid or Amsterdam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Aaron Judge Sets a Deadline for His Yankees Future
description: The slugging outfielder wants to stay with the team that drafted him, but he does not want to talk about a contract extension once the season begins.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees’ first game of the 2022 regular season is three weeks away. By then, their biggest star, who is entering his final season before free agency, hopes to have clarity on his future with the team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Zelensky’s Plea to Congress
description: Biden announced $800 million in new military aid to Ukraine.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Farwell
title: With ‘Welcome to Flatch,’ Paul Feig Comes Home
description: Not since “Freaks and Geeks” has the director of “Bridesmaids” been so involved in a network TV show. It’s just one reason this small-town comedy felt right.
content: In conversation, Paul Feig is unusually candid about his experiences: upbeat, openhearted, but not falsely modest. So he paused only briefly when asked whether he had learned anything about making television since creating — and quickly losing — the critically beloved high school comedy “Freaks and Geeks” (1999-2000), which was summarily canceled after one season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Karl Russell
title: Why rates are going up.
description: The central bank wants a strong economy, but sustainability is the name of the game: A little pain today could mean less pain tomorrow.
content: Prices for groceries, couches and rent are all climbing rapidly, and Federal Reserve officials have been warily eyeing that trend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Malin
title: Love Is in the Air. So Is Dander.
description: When marriages between humans slowed because of the pandemic, ceremonies uniting two animals only became more popular.
content: Read more about the 2022 wedding boom in our ongoing Year of the Wedding series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: A Hollywood Production (Made in Liverpool)
description: Netflix, Amazon Prime and other studios are snapping up soundstages in Britain and building more, drawn by an experienced labor pool and alluring tax incentives.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — For two decades, the Littlewoods building in Liverpool, a long, low-slung and cavernous space built to house a betting and mail-order company in the 1930s, sat abandoned. No one wanted to take on this crumbling hulk looming on the outskirts of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Miriam Jordan
title: Biden Offers Protected Status to Afghans Already in the United States
description: The program does not provide a path to a green card or citizenship, which many advocates say is warranted for Afghans who risked their lives to assist U.S. forces.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is allowing Afghans who have been residing in the United States to remain in the country legally for at least another 18 months, an attempt to provide them more stability as gaining permanent residency could take years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Putin Is ‘High Off His Own Propaganda Supply’
description: Peter Pomerantsev discusses the Kremlin’s war on information.
content: This week, an antiwar protester interrupted a Moscow broadcast with a sign in Russian reading: “Stop the war. Don’t believe the propaganda. They are lying to you here.” With the Russian government promoting propaganda on news channels and most recently passing a law to punish people spreading “false information” about the Ukraine invasion, it’s been hard to distill what is actually going on in both Russia and Ukraine right now. The confusion has resulted in what Masha Gessen recently described as parallel realities transpiring in Russia and an outright denial of war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Fear Factor and Crime in New York
description: Recent arrests of mentally ill people in highly publicized violent crimes have unsettled New Yorkers.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at arrests in two high-profile cases — and how random crimes have added to the fear factor in New York. We’ll also get a first glimpse of a photograph of a man killed in the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Paul Mozur
title: Beating Japan at Its Own (Video) Game: A Smash Hit From China
description: Genshin Impact, a nearly picture-perfect reproduction of Japanese fantasy role-playing games, has raked in billions of dollars and sent shock waves through the world’s aging video game superpower.
content: TOKYO — Genshin Impact, one of the world’s hottest mobile video games, has all the characteristics of a Japanese invention: giant robots; human-size swords; characters with huge eyes and spiky, rainbow-colored hair; and a puzzling fixation on women in maid outfits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Many Schools Aren’t Made for Kids With Learning Differences. The Pandemic Amplified That.
description: We’re still finding out how much learning loss children experienced.
content: When I think of the parents I’ve interviewed in the past two years, some of the most affected in the early days of the pandemic were those whose children have learning disabilities or differences. Remote school was hard for everyone, but it was particularly difficult for families whose children — 14 percent of all American public school students — needed additional support to learn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Treasury Shifts $377 Million Among States as Pandemic Housing Aid Dries Up
description: The Biden administration pulled back the aid from states and counties with unspent funds and diverted it to four states pressing for more: California, New York, New Jersey and Illinois.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has clawed back $377 million in federal emergency housing aid from states and counties, most of them controlled by Republicans, and redirected the cash to states that have been clamoring for more help, including New York, California and New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Pillowy Magic of Milk Bread
description: Milk bread at its best is soft and almost sweet, with a wispy, ethereal texture.
content: Baking a loaf of milk bread is the closest I’ll ever get to time travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: As Jackson Faces Senators, Her Criminal Defense Record Is a Target
description: Republicans have vilified Biden’s judicial nominees who have represented criminal suspects. Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, for the Supreme Court, is the most prominent.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Josh Hawley had a pointed question earlier this month for a federal appeals court nominee who, as a public defender, helped get a Pennsylvania man off death row despite his conviction for two brutal murders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: House Democrats Ask Pentagon for Details on Plan to Reduce Civilian Casualties
description: In a letter on Tuesday, more than 40 lawmakers called it imperative that the military uphold “consistent standards for protecting the lives of civilians.”
content: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats called on the Defense Department on Tuesday to brief Congress on the administration’s progress toward reducing civilian injuries and deaths from U.S. military operations overseas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
title: As Russian Troop Deaths Climb, Morale Becomes an Issue, Officials Say
description: More than 7,000 Russian troops have been killed in less than three weeks of fighting, according to conservative U.S. estimates.
content: WASHINGTON — In 36 days of fighting on Iwo Jima during World War II, nearly 7,000 Marines were killed. Now, 20 days after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia invaded Ukraine, his military has already lost more soldiers, according to American intelligence estimates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Nine Dead, Including Coach and Six College Golfers, in Texas Wreck
description: The University of the Southwest said its golf coach, Tyler James, was among the dead and that two people were in critical condition.
content: The University of the Southwest’s golf teams were making the kind of drive familiar to athletes at plenty of small colleges — aboard a passenger van around sunset and after a day of competition — on Tuesday night when a pickup rumbled into view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai, Megan Specia and Emma Bubola
title: After Six-Year Ordeal in Iran, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe Is Freed
description: Ms. Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a charity worker, was arrested and detained in Tehran in 2016. She was released along with another dual citizen of Iran and the U.K. after the resolution of a longstanding British debt.
content: LONDON — After six years in Tehran separated from her family, first in prison and then under house arrest, a British-Iranian woman’s ordeal in detention in Iran is finally over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Michael D. Shear
title: Invoking America’s Darkest Days, Zelensky Pleads for More U.S. Aid
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called for a no-fly zone and more weapons to combat Russia’s assault and implored President Biden to be “the leader of peace.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine invoked the memory of America’s darkest days on Wednesday as he pleaded for more military aid to combat Russia’s “inhumane destruction” of his country, directly challenging President Biden and members of Congress to help by showing a wrenching video of the carnage in Ukraine’s cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: Michael Bublé Always Finds a Way
description: Hustle, charm and a remarkable ability to slot himself into songs have made the musician a star — even though his style has never aligned with pop trends.
content: Michael Bublé had a lot to share in the first five minutes of a recent video chat. He hates having to use the bathroom at a movie theater, because the idea of missing a crucial plot point is stressful. The creamy vegetable soup he apologized for eating on camera — not great. He also did not care for “The Matrix Resurrections,” the 2021 installment of the sci-fi franchise; that said, he loves Keanu Reeves, who lives on his street in Los Angeles. Though they’ve never met, every time Bublé and his family pass the actor’s house, they say, out loud, “Hi, Keanu.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden announces $800 million in military aid for Ukraine.
description: President Biden’s announcement came hours after Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, delivered a virtual address to Congress and pleaded for more help in defending against Russia’s invasion.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Wednesday that the United States would send $800 million in additional military assistance to Ukraine, shortly after the country’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, delivered an impassioned virtual address to Congress in which he appealed for more help in staving off Russia’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: The Players Throwing It Back (to the Basket)
description: While bigs are increasingly encouraged to develop a 3-point shot, Kentucky’s Oscar Tshiebwe and Illinois’s Kofi Cockburn are averaging double-doubles with their efforts in the post.
content: Men’s college basketball observers appreciate the nostalgia that Kentucky’s Oscar Tshiebwe and Illinois’s Kofi Cockburn conjure just as much as they value their mastery in the post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Will the Ukraine War End the Age of Populism?
description: Populism’s poor fit for this particular moment has given an opportunity to its enemies and critics.
content: If the past 10 years of Western history have featured an extended wrestling match between populism and liberalism, Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine has inspired many liberals to hopefully declare the contest over, their opponent pinned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Valerie Hopkins and Carlotta Gall
title: Ukrainian Forces Strike Back at Russia, as Biden Sends More Firepower
description: The attacks in Kyiv and Kherson were aimed at inflicting “maximum losses” against Russia but not regaining territory, while the U.S. pledged $800 million more in military aid.
content: ODESSA, Ukraine — Ukrainian forces carried out counter-offensives against Russian positions on Wednesday, seeking to inflict what one official called “maximum losses,” even as the invading Russian military stepped up its lethal attacks on cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Wheeler
title: The Milk and Cookies Cake Roxane Gay Swears By
description: Frosted with buttercream and finished with chocolate chips, this confection is so good you don’t need a special occasion to bake it, the writer says.
content: Roxane Gay is mastering the art of cake decorating. “When the pandemic started, I decided to begin teaching myself,” the writer and critic explained recently. So far, she has nailed base coats, florets and borders. According to Gay, there is still room for improvement. “I cannot make a frosting rose to save my life and I have no artistic ability, so pretty much all my decorated cakes look the same,” she said. “But it’s fine because they taste great.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Zelensky urges more leaders to visit Kyiv after a visit by prime ministers of 3 NATO nations.
description: The leaders from Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia “fear nothing,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said, and he urged other leaders to make similar visits.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky thanked the leaders of three NATO member countries who traveled into Ukraine’s war-torn capital for an extraordinary meeting on Tuesday and urged others to do the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why Gardening Offers a ‘Psychological Lifeline’ in Times of Crisis
description: According to the English psychiatrist Sue Stuart-Smith, it was no accident that we had a run on seeds at the beginning of the pandemic.
content: We sow a first flat of seeds; we gently rake debris from a bed to make way for a winter aconite or snowdrop to poke through and cheer us. And so it begins, again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilia Krasilshchik
title: Russians Must Accept the Truth. We Failed.
description: Now we must bear that failure.
content: TBILISI, Georgia — “Wake up, Sonya, the war has started.” These were the first words I said to my girlfriend on the morning of Feb. 24, as Russian missiles rained down on Ukraine. The words I’d never thought I’d have to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Volkswagen eyes U.S. market as war in Ukraine disrupts European production.
description: Focusing on electric vehicles, Volkswagen aims for growth in North America, though it could face tough competition.
content: Volkswagen is shifting its focus toward North America, as the fallout from Russia’s attack on Ukraine caused more supply chain headaches for the company in Europe, executives said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Tour a House Full of Black History’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about a 90-year-old former schoolteacher’s private collection of Black history artifacts. Then, they will create an art exhibit highlighting several objects from the collection.
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times in general. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Nadia Shira Cohen
title: ‘They Don’t Know About War’: The Legacy of Forgotten Horrors
description: Two-thirds of Cambodians are under the age of 30 — born decades after the Khmer Rouge’s totalitarian terror and the American carpet-bombing campaign.
content: SNA ANSA, Cambodia — The land mine that killed Ma Simet and two others was laid decades ago. The devices are designed to endure. They can outlast monsoons and droughts, years of political upheaval and submerged histories — until the cataclysmic moment of contact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The W.H.O. puts off assessing Russia’s Sputnik vaccine because of the war in Ukraine.
description: An official with the World Health Organization said “the assessment, along with inspections, have been affected.”
content: Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine against the coronavirus will have to wait longer for a decision on emergency use authorization by the World Health Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Yankees’ Infield Is Complete, but Comes With Questions
description: By bringing back first baseman Anthony Rizzo, the Yankees have a solid player at each infield position. But they also passed on all of the top-tier free agents.
content: By bringing back first baseman Anthony Rizzo on a two-year contract, the Yankees’ 2022 infield is now complete. But some big questions loom for a team that is no longer at the top of baseball’s spending perch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Forget I Wrote That
description: Joseph Gangi’s debut puts grid art to good use.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I know that I am on the record as not being the biggest fan of grid art. Please, forget I ever wrote that. This puzzle, a debut by Joseph Gangi, has forever changed my opinion of grid art. This is truly the best use of black squares to create an image that I have ever encountered, and I swear I am not being hyperbolic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: U.S. labor board issues a complaint against Starbucks.
description: A National Labor Relations Board office said the chain had illegally penalized two Arizona workers, the first such finding in the recent unionization push.
content: The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint against Starbucks on Tuesday over accusations that it retaliated against two employees seeking to unionize their store in Phoenix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What a Federal Reserve Rate Increase Means for You
description: Rates on credit cards, savings accounts and different kinds of loans move when the Fed changes its benchmark rate. Here’s what you need to know.
content: Consumers are already feeling squeezed by higher prices on daily necessities, whether it’s at the gas pump or in the supermarket. And now that interest rates are ticking higher, the cost of borrowing — from credit cards and car financing to private student loans — will increase, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Chinese Officer Charged With Harassing N.Y. Congressional Candidate
description: Yan Xiong, a Chinese dissident who immigrated to America and is now a political candidate in New York, was targeted by an agent of the Chinese government, federal prosecutors said.
content: Five people acting as agents of the Chinese secret police stalked and harassed American-based Chinese critics of the Beijing government — including a candidate for Congress in New York, a California-based artist, and the father of an Olympic figure skater — in an effort to silence dissident voices, federal prosecutors said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: A Russian Ballet Star, Opposed to the Ukraine War, Quits the Bolshoi
description: Olga Smirnova said she was against the war in Ukraine “with all the fibers of my soul.” Now, she has joined the Dutch National Ballet.
content: Olga Smirnova, who has for over a decade been a star of the Bolshoi, the Russian company whose name is synonymous with ballet, has left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Brain-Imaging Studies Hampered by Small Data Sets, Study Finds
description: Researchers have long used imaging technology to try to understand mental-health ailments. But with relatively few participants, such studies may not be producing valid findings.
content: For two decades, researchers have used brain-imaging technology to try to identify how the structure and function of a person’s brain connects to a range of mental-health ailments, from anxiety and depression to suicidal tendencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: ‘The Era of the Foreign Correspondent Is Over’: Justin Smith on His Media Start-Up
description: The former Bloomberg Media C.E.O. offered new details on the venture he is starting with the journalist Ben Smith.
content: It will be named for a word that is the same in dozens of languages. It will recruit English-speaking journalists from countries like India and Singapore to cover the news. And according to its co-founder, “The era of the foreign correspondent is over.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson travels to Saudi Arabia for oil diplomacy.
description: At home, critics had another take on Mr. Johnson’s efforts to reduce western reliance on Russian energy.
content: LONDON — Stepping up the search for alternatives to Russian energy, Britain’s Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, on Wednesday visited Saudi Arabia in hopes of persuading the oil producer to boost output and relieve pressure on global markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: ‘We Want People That Are Going to Fight the Left,’ Says the Man Out-Trumping Trump
description: Ron DeSantis might well match or exceed the former president as liberals’ worst nightmare.
content: Ron DeSantis, the Republican governor of Florida, is giving Donald Trump a run for his money as the most divisive politician in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: G.O.P. Senate Hopeful Faces Scrutiny Over Handling of Teacher Pensions
description: David McCormick, a Republican Senate candidate in Pennsylvania, came under attack from his chief rival, Dr. Mehmet Oz, over the underperformance of investments for the state’s teachers.
content: Before he entered Pennsylvania’s Senate race, David McCormick oversaw a giant hedge fund that invested billions of dollars for the retirement plans of the state’s teachers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Chris Cuomo seeks $125 million from CNN.
description: Mr. Cuomo’s lawyers claim the money is owed to him for wrongful termination.
content: The former cable news anchor Chris Cuomo is seeking $125 million from CNN for what his lawyers claim was wrongful termination when the cable news network fired him in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: What the Ukraine War Means for the Future of Climate Change
description: European leaders are realizing they can no longer depend  on Russian fossil fuels. But whether renewable energy fills the gap is an open question.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: A Mother’s Wild, Extravagant Love
description: She couldn’t be physically present for her daughter’s life. But she found a way to be there, still.
content: Genevieve Kingston has carried a cardboard box with her throughout her life, filled with gifts for major milestones — childhood birthdays, her first period, graduation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Una Mullally
title: A Celtic Revival, in Hip-Hop and More
description: The trio Kneecap is pioneering Irish-language rap, a genre that barely existed a decade ago.
content: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — On a recent evening in a small, rowdy, West Belfast bar, Mo Chara and Móglaí Bap, two members of the rap group Kneecap, were posing for photographs with fans. One of the bar’s patrons, tapping out a text message nearby, called out to the rappers, “How do you spell ‘ceart go leor’?” an Irish phrase meaning something like “OK.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten, Michael Gonchar and Jeremy Engle
title: Teaching Resources to Help Students Make Sense of the War in Ukraine
description: Articles, maps, photos, videos, podcasts and more, as well as suggestions for using them in your classroom.
content: Young people all over are avidly following what some have called “the first TikTok war.” In late February, we created a place on our site for teenagers to react to the invasion, and within a week, over 900 had. This comment from Winn Godier, a high school student in North Carolina, echoes what we have heard from many teenagers:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Eric Schmitt
title: Iran’s Attack Was Response to Secret Israeli Attack on Drone Site
description: Israel and Iran are pushing the boundaries of a long-running clandestine war that is increasingly spilling out of the shadows.
content: Iran fired a barrage of ballistic missiles into Iraq over the weekend, striking what it claimed was an Israeli target and leaving some analysts scratching their heads about what exactly precipitated the blitz and why Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Ballerina Finds Her Modern Dance Home: It ‘Feels Limitless’
description: Lauren Lovette, a former principal with New York City Ballet, has been named the resident choreographer of the Paul Taylor Dance Company.
content: Lauren Lovette has a new job that would have been unthinkable a few years ago — not only for herself but for the dance world. Until the fall, Lovette was an esteemed principal at New York City Ballet, but now she has crossed over into modern dance and has been named the first resident choreographer at the Paul Taylor Dance Company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Is the Coolest Thing You Have Seen in Nature?
description: Once a year at Yosemite National Park in California, a waterfall turns into a “firefall.” Have you ever seen anything in nature that made you say “wow”?
content: Do you enjoy spending time outdoors? Are you fascinated by the natural world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. Casts a Global Net to Stop Shipments to Russia
description: To try to halt the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and its allies have imposed the most sweeping export controls seen in decades on Russia. Now they have to enforce them.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States, in partnership with its allies, has hit Russia with some of the most sweeping export restrictions ever imposed, barring companies across the world from sending advanced technology in order to penalize President Vladimir V. Putin for his invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Voters Oust Mayor of Florida Town Where Condo Tower Collapsed
description: Charles Burkett was the mayor of Surfside when the 13-story Champlain Towers South complex fell in June, killing 98 people. He lost his re-election bid by 33 votes on Tuesday.
content: The mayor who led the seaside town of Surfside, Fla., through the traumatic aftermath of the collapse of a condominium tower in which 98 people were killed last year was voted out of office on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Annie Flanders, Founder of Details Magazine, Dies at 82
description: Her idiosyncratic and fiercely independent magazine chronicled Downtown Manhattan in the 1980s, a combustible mix of art, music and fashion.
content: Annie Flanders, the ardent, russet-haired founding editor of Details magazine, the proudly independent chronicle of Downtown Manhattan in the 1980s, died on March 10 at an assisted living facility in Los Angeles. She was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: Riverhead, N.Y.: A Long Island Community That’s Suddenly Popular
description: To many, the Suffolk County town has long been a signpost rather than a destination. But recently, it has been giving people a reason to hang around.
content: Beth Anne Pike has been selling real estate in Riverhead, N.Y., for 20 years and cannot quite explain the town’s sudden popularity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder and Michael Forsythe
title: Spain seizes another Russian yacht believed to belong to an oligarch.
description: The ship was impounded in the Spanish port of Tarragona pending an inspection to establish its exact ownership, Spain’s transport ministry said.
content: MADRID — Spain, which has pledged to seize the suspected superyachts of Russian oligarchs targeted for sanctions imposed following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, on Wednesday impounded the third such vessel, one of the world’s biggest superyachts, in Spanish territorial waters this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Cano ‘Can’t Live in the Past.’ But Can He Change?
description: Cano, who has served two suspensions for performance-enhancing drug use, apologized to his Mets teammates. But at 39, he finds himself on a team that no longer needs him.
content: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — In the first inning of the Mets’ first simulated game on Wednesday, Robinson Cano took a pitch off the shoulder from David Peterson. “We’re on the same team!” J.D. Davis hollered from the on-deck circle, and everyone laughed. Cano stayed in the box and hung in against a breaking ball, pulling it foul but swinging with confidence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Standing in Russia’s Way as the Bodies Pile Up and Life Goes On
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 16, 2022.
content: “They’re not even giving him to me so that I can wash him. I have to take him away in a bag, a garbage bag.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea’s Projectile Launch Fails, South Korea Says
description: The projectile, fired from outside Pyongyang, failed “immediately after liftoff,” the South Korean military said.
content: SEOUL — North Korea launched an unidentified projectile on Wednesday, but it apparently failed “immediately after liftoff,” the South Korean military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch, Jennifer Medina, Jazmine Ulloa and Maya King
title: Russia’s Attack Rallies a Divided Nation: The United States
description: Americans across the political spectrum express broad support for Ukraine, though opinions diverge on what that means and how far the U.S. response should go.
content: After two years of political divisions and economic disruptions bolstered by an unending pandemic, many Americans say they are coming together around a common cause: support for Ukraine, a country under daily siege by Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Is Wowed by the Senate Actually Doing Something
description: “Various politicians have been trying to do this for years but they kept getting clock blocked,” Jimmy Kimmel said of the Sunshine Protection Act, which passed Tuesday in the Senate.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Nancy Wartik
title: Africa’s Vaccine Challenge
description: Covid vaccination rates in Africa are still worryingly low, averaging about 14 percent.
content: Covid vaccination rates in Africa are still worryingly low — averaging about 14 percent across the continent — and public health experts expect Africa to experience a fifth wave of the virus in the coming months. That could potentially take the form of a new, more lethal variant that could endanger the entire world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Cross-Body Bags for Those on the Go
description: Hands-free purses perfect for spring jaunts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: As Russia Digs In, What’s the Risk of Nuclear War? ‘It’s Not Zero.’
description: A series of shifts in Russian statements about using nuclear weapons has led some analysts to believe that the Kremlin sees a nuclear exchange as a viable strategy.
content: A major war raging on Russia’s and NATO’s borders. Increasingly bold Western military support. Russian threats of direct retaliation. A mood of siege and desperation in the Kremlin. Growing uncertainty around each side’s red lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Being Outspent by the Mets, the Yankees’ Owner Defends His Payroll
description: With an expensive roster, and high expenses, Hal Steinbrenner brushed off talk of pressure from the Mets’ Steven A. Cohen. “I can’t control what resources other owners or other teams have.”
content: TAMPA, Fla. — For so long in Major League Baseball, the Yankees sat atop the payroll rankings. George Steinbrenner, the billionaire who reigned over the team for 37 years until his death in 2010, loved to spend and to win. His franchise earned seven World Series titles during his stewardship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Citing a Chevron Tanker, Ukraine Seeks Tougher Restrictions at Russian Ports
description: A top Ukrainian official criticized companies in the United States and Greece for helping Russia continue to profit from oil despite its attack on Ukraine.
content: Oil tankers from around the world, including several chartered by U.S.-based companies, are continuing to transport millions of barrels of oil out of Russian ports, a top adviser to Ukraine’s president said, as he made a plea to the White House to restrict all trade in Russian oil by American companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘Book of Mountains & Seas,’ Puppets Embark on Mythic Quests
description: Huang Ruo and Basil Twist’s new choral-theater piece at St. Ann’s Warehouse borrows from traditional Chinese tales.
content: The giant is immense and craggy-limbed, like some primordial creature hewed from the earth or forged from lava. His name is Kua Fu, and in Huang Ruo and Basil Twist’s new choral-theater piece “Book of Mountains & Seas” he is a puppet, towering above his team of puppeteers. When thirst strikes, he lies prostrate to lap up a whole river of white silk, which slips down his gullet and disappears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Minx’ Reveals That All Nudity Is Not Created Equal
description: Even at a time when naked men have become more commonplace on TV, a scene in the pilot of this HBO Max comedy stands out for its variety and realism.
content: A year and a half ago, when it came time to cast a particular scene in the pilot episode of “Minx,” the showrunner Ellen Rapoport sifted through hundreds of photos of background actors, which had already been sorted into piles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Two Former Governors Weigh In on California’s Bullet Train
description: California’s monumental effort to build a high-speed rail system is at a crossroads. Plus, daylight saving time may become permanent.
content: Maybe you haven’t thought much about California’s plan to build a high-speed rail line connecting Los Angeles and San Francisco since you voted for (or against) the nearly $10 billion bond measure to get the project started in 2008.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Prosecutors Won’t Charge Police Officers in 2 High-Profile Killings in Chicago
description: The Cook County state’s attorney said the officers might have violated departmental policy in the deaths of two armed suspects — including a 13-year-old — but that criminal charges weren’t warranted.
content: Prosecutors in Chicago said on Tuesday that they would not file charges against the officers who fatally shot 13-year-old Adam Toledo and 22-year-old Anthony Alvarez, killings that occurred two days apart in March 2021 and put a spotlight on the Police Department’s chase policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: She Discovered What Happened to 400 Dutch Jews Who Disappeared
description: In a new exhibition, Wally de Lang, a Dutch historian, has tracked what happened to each of the men rounded up in the first Nazi raids on Dutch Jews, whose fates have largely been a mystery for decades.
content: AMSTERDAM — In February 1941, nine months after the German Reich invaded and occupied the Netherlands, the first pogroms began on Dutch soil. Local Nazi party members posted bills in shop and cafe windows that read “Jews Not Wanted.” Then they trolled the Jewish Quarter, breaking windows and shouting jeers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan and Peter Fisher
title: The Secret Sounds of ‘Dune’: Rice Krispies and Marianne Faithfull
description: Denis Villeneuve and his sound team explain how far they went to achieve an aural experience that would feel somewhat familiar, an unusual approach for sci-fi.
content: “Dune” is in the details, and Denis Villeneuve knows nearly all of them. The French Canadian filmmaker grew up obsessed with Frank Herbert’s seminal sci-fi novel and has spent the last few years of his life adapting that 1965 book into a budding film franchise. The first installment came out in October and the second one will begin shooting later this year, so if there’s anything you want to know about the inner workings of “Dune,” Villeneuve is the man to ask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Try a stovetop salmon recipe simple enough for dorm cooking, from Genevieve Ko.
content: Good morning. Genevieve Ko is in The Times this week with a lovely dispatch from Dublin, where she traveled to get one of her daughters settled at college. There is no meal plan at the school, so her daughter will have to cook for herself. Genevieve scouted nearby shops with her, though, and came up with an ace recipe for her daughter to prepare: whiskey-glazed salmon with salt-crusted potatoes (above).

title: Corrections: March 16, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 16, 2022.
content: An article on Tuesday about the ways that China could benefit from the war in Ukraine misspelled the surname of the German chancellor. He is Olaf Scholz, not Sholz.
